newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU foreign ministers to tackle fur-trap issue.
newsitem.headline: EU foreign ministers to tackle fur-trap issue.

text.p: European Union foreign ministers are due to discuss in Luxembourg on Monday a draft deal with Canada and Russia on standards for traps used to catch animals for their fur.
Negotiators from Canada, Russia and the European Commission have initialled a deal, replacing one previously rejected as too weak by EU environment ministers.

In the revised deal, Canada has accepted a ban, effective immediately the agreement comes into force, on all types of jaw-type, leghold traps for seven of 12 Canadian species under consideration, EU diplomats said on Friday.
Use of such traps for the remaining five species will be outlawed from March 31, 2000 provided the deal is in place before October 1 this year.
Russia will ban the traps by December 31, 1999 "if adequate financial assistance is provided to replace existing traps".
If not, the traps will be phased out at the latest four years after agreement comes into force.
The revised text also removes any derogation from the ban for trappers among Canada's indigenous populations and limits Russia's derogation to the use of a traditional wooden trap.

Difficulties remain in the way of an EU trapping deal with the United States, which considers the deal too strict and where questions remain about the division of powers, between federal and state authorities, to negotiate on trapping.
